stem: A client with an indwelling urinary catheter has a temperature of 102.8Â°F (39.3Â°C), heart rate 124, and blood pressure 82/40 mmHg. The client remains hypotensive after a 2L intravenous fluid bolus. Complete the clinical bowtie.

actions.text: Administer furosemide intravenously to reduce fluid overload

rationale.correct: Septic shock is characterized by systemic inflammation (c1) and massive vasodilation (c2). Since fluid boluses failed to adequately increase blood pressure, norepinephrine (a1) is needed to increase vascular resistance. Cultures (a2) are diagnostic and guide antibiotic therapy. Mean arterial pressure (MAP) (p1) and serial serum lactate levels (p2) are the primary monitoring parameters for shock resolution.
rationale.incorrect: Furosemide (a3) would worsen the shock by further reducing preload. Oral antibiotics (a4) are too slow; intravenous administration is required.

clinicalPearls: Target MAP is typically >= 65 mmHg in septic shock to ensure adequate organ perfusion.
Early recognition and treatment of sepsis are crucial to improving patient outcomes.

questionTrap.howToOvercome: Don't be afraid to continue fluid resuscitation or initiate vasopressors in sepsis; avoid diuretics even if the client appears 'edematous' as they are likely experiencing capillary leak and third spacing of fluids.
